content.description: A great unique climb that starts at the river and finishes beneath the power pole.  Start is very difficult, but with two close bolts to assist ascent if necessary.  The rest of the climb uses good holds and has a substantial rest section in the middle if needed.
content.location: Found on Lower Wall, beneath the power pole rectangle frame on the South Rim Wall.

content.description: Like the Russian behemoth, this climb is strong out of the gate but much quieter in the finish.  The crux is the very difficult start.  An easier variation is to start on the climb Dvatsat just to the north and traverse across the slopey ledge to the climb.  The traverse has an intermediate bolt placed between the two climbs for extra safety.
content.location: Found on the lower wall beneath the climb Yee-Haw on the South Rim Wall.  Look for a few small trees growing right at the edge of the river out of the bedrock.

content.description: This is the twentieth route bolted at Camp Eagle.  This climb starts on a slopely ledge and then moves up into solid holds.  Consistent moves and difficulty throughout.
content.location: Located on Lower Wall, beneath Yee-Haw on South Rim Wall.  Look for small trees growing out of the bedrock at the river's edge, and for nearby climb Red October.

content.description: In the cave below the rappel deck. Really cool holes in the ceiling of the cave lead to crux roof pull and easy face to top out.

This climbing wall is found beneath the South Rim Wall and is the area with the most immediate access to the river.  The climbs here are distinguished by tricky starts but interesting features not found elsewhere on the cliff.  Use the guidebook from Camp Eagle's website to find the climbs on this wall.
